intro: Allium subhirsutum subsp. ciliare, commonly known as the woolly garlic or the ciliate garlic, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its dense, woolly leaves and clusters of small, white to pale purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained, rocky soils. Its bulbs are edible and have a mild garlic flavor, making it a valued plant in some traditional cuisines. It is also cultivated for its ornamental value due to its attractive foliage and flowering display.
